title: Introduce message limit in the new console frontend. r=linclark
body:
This is working well, but I'm unsure about the overall architecture.
Should the prune reducer be in its own file ?
Is the way I declare the reducer in createStore correct ?
If I'm correct, combineReducers lead to having only the property with the same name (messages in our case) as state argument of the reducer, but in this case we need to have access to the root state object in order to get the prefs.

title: Add filtering bar
body:
I think you wanted to have this done by today, so I'm posting what I have for now. 

**What's working :** 
- clear the logs
- search the log (basic)
- show/hide the "configure filters" bar
- filtering message by their security level
- clearing the filters


**What need to be done:**
- advanced search
- show/hide the "there are filtered messages.." based on the filters
- actually set the corresponding preferences when toggling the button 
- add Persist Log checkbox ( and setting the preference)
- add CSS/Network/XHR pills when we have figure out what to do
- use l10N for labels and title
- add tests


**What is buggy :**
- the filter bar do not stick to the top. I don't really know XUL, and I'm struggling doing this. Should I render the ConsoleOutput on an ancestor node of the one we're using now (`outputNode`) ?
- the "show hide configure filter bar" button does not have "active" style when the bar is shown
- clicking on the search input sometimes does not add the focus on the input (it looks like it blurs as soon as it get focused)


 @linclark @bgrins please tell me is there things I can do better.
I hope I don't slow you down, tomorrow is holiday in France and I took a PTO on Friday so I'll have some extra time to dedicate to this.

title: Add collapsible stacktrace for console.error/trace messages. r=linclark
body:
Fixes #91 & #90 

As mentioned in #90 I added an `open` property to the state which is an array of ids. 
This is working well, except one thing. In the current console, console.trace() have open stacktrace by default. I don't know how to do that with the solution I put up. Should I dispatch a `messageOpen` action in the messages reducers for trace message ? Or is it something smarter we can do ?

title: Match against stacktrace in text filter
body:
Since a stacktrace is an array of frame, we add a function
to test if a string is included in a frame, and we use it
when testing the message's location and its stacktrace - for
each frame of the stack.

Adds some test to ensure we match the function name and the
location in the stacktrace, as well as test to make sur we
don't get unwanted messages.

Fixes #270

## Testing instructions
1. run `npm test`

repo.name: gecko-dev
repo.description: The console.html team's fork of Firefox

title: Add console.group support
body:
Fixes #44

Test instructions : 
1. `npm test`

@linclark @bgrins I think this is working pretty well like this. I wanted to have your opinion about it before the weekend, so I can change what needs to be, and write the tests. 

The main ideas here are: 
- we add a `group` property on the state, which is a map which contains the parent groups of a group
- we add a `currentGroup` in order to assign the id of the latest created group in a `groupId` on the message
- we re-use the existing `messagesUiById` to track the open/closed state of the group
- in the selector, we only return the message which are in an opened group
- when pruning, if there is one, we output the last non-closed group

Since I added a lot of thing in the messages selector, I revamped how we do the filtering to something simpler to understand IMO.

I tweaked the design a little bit, but I think we could have a follow-up with helen's take on this. 

And that's it :) Please tell me what you think about this, I'll do my best to have it done over the week-end. Thanks !
